questions.question_text: An administrator is deploying Cisco Expressways for Mobile and Remote Access. The registration domain is “example.com”, and the Expressway-E FQDN is “expe.example.com”. Cisco Jabber clients on the internet cannot discover services via DNS lookup. Which SRV records must be configured in the public DNS to allow Service Discovery?

discussion.content:
To allow service discovery for Cisco Jabber clients on the internet, the following SRV (Service) records must be configured in the public DNS:

A. _collab-edge._tls.example.com

The "_collab-edge._tls" SRV record is used for Cisco Expressway-E Mobile and Remote Access. By configuring this SRV record under the domain "example.com", clients will be able to discover the correct Expressway-E server for establishing secure connections for Mobile and Remote Access.

choices.D: The Cisco UC server establishes a connection using the outgoing path through the Cisco Expressways that terminates in the Cisco Webex Cloud to create the hybrid environment that links the two services together.
choices.B: The Expressway-E located in the DMZ establishes a connection with the Cisco Webex Cloud to enable the hybrid service and allow the two services to communicate.
choices.A: The Expressway-C enables a connection directly with the Cisco Webex Cloud to enable the hybrid service and allow the two services to communicate.
choices.C: The Cisco Unified IM and Presence server establishes a connection using the outgoing path through the Cisco Expressways that terminates in the Cisco Webex Cloud to create the hybrid environment that links the two services together.

questions.question_text: How is the communication routed in a Hybrid deployment so that people on Cisco Cloud-Based IM are able to communicate with Cisco Jabber users in the on-premises environment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Hybrid Message Connections

Figure 11. Hybrid Message Connections

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cloudCollaboration/spark/hybridservices/messageservice/cmgt_b_spark-hybrid-message-deployment-guide/cmgt_b_spark-hybrid-message-deployment-guide_chapter_00.html

comments.content: Isn't technically the Expwe who does the connections to the cloud? Expwc provides the secure connection traversing the traffic. Expwc technically doesn't have any access to the internet in order to directly form a connection.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Exp-C connector server used for hybrid deployments

choices.B: On the Expressway-E, run diagnostic logging under maintenance to see if any requests reach the system.
choices.A: On the Cisco UCM, run the Real-Time Monitoring Tool to see if any incoming calls fail.
choices.D: On the Expressway-C, run a network log under administrative tools to see if any requests reach the system.
choices.C: On the Expressway-E, check the NTP settings to ensure that TLS will be able to terminate. If the clock is out of sync, incoming calls from other working systems would work bur not outgoing calls from the company.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Agree with Duke

Given the scenario provided, where calls from outside the company are not being received and the initial checks show no apparent issues with the endpoints, SIP trunk, or traversal link, the most appropriate action for the engineer to take to troubleshoot the issue is:

B. On the Expressway-E, run diagnostic logging under maintenance to see if any requests reach the system.

By examining the diagnostic logging on the Expressway-E, the engineer can determine whether incoming calls are reaching the system. This step will help identify if there are any issues with the Expressway-E receiving incoming calls from external sources. It's a crucial next step in the troubleshooting process to pinpoint where the breakdown in communication might be occurring.

questions.question_text: An engineer learns from an end user that calls from outside the company are not being received. Calls are being made to other businesses outside of the company on video using URL addresses. The change management log shows no changes in the configuration of the collaboration solutions. The engineer examines the endpoint, which seems to be registered to the Cisco UCM, and the SIP trunk between the Cisco UCM and sees that the Expressway is also up. In addition, the traversal link shows no errors between the Expressways. Which action must the engineer take to troubleshoot this issue?
Which protocol and port are used for signaling between on-premises Cisco Webex Video Mesh Nodes and Cloud Media Services?

choices.C: standard SIP TLS over TCP port 5061

discussion.content:
B is correct...
...444 port references from Requirements for Proxy Support for Video Mesh, Ports and Protocols for Management, Configure Video Mesh Node for Proxy Integration, and Configure Video Mesh Node for Proxy Integration

Correct answer is D. The only type of signaling between WVM Nodes and Cloud media services is cascade signaling which uses TCP Port 444.
Source:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cloudCollaboration/spark/hybridservices/videomesh/cmgt_b_webex-video-mesh-deployment-guide/cmgt_b_hybrid-media-deployment-guide_chapter_010.html#reference_931D7E96CA43B51A44E9A01B14BEB0F4
Both B and D are correct. 443 is used for general signaling, 444 is used for cascade signaling

comments.content: But the question is not saying anything about cascade just signaling, in that case should be 443 I think and B as correct answer
D is correct ignore the above

I'm sorry, but the correct answer is B. signaling over HTTPS TCP port 443, not D. signaling over TCP port 444.

On-premises Cisco Webex Video Mesh Nodes use HTTPS over port 443 to signal with Cloud Media Services. This communication is secured with SSL/TLS encryption. HTTPS is the protocol used for secure communication over the internet and port 443 is the default port for HTTPS traffic.

Option D is not correct because there is no mention of signaling over port 444 in the documentation for Cisco Webex Video Mesh.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Table 4-3 Traffic Signatures for Cascade Signaling to the Webex Cloud Media Services
Source - Video Mesh Node
Destination - Webex Cloud Media Services
Source Address - ANY
Source Port - ANY
Protocol - TCP
Destination Address - ANY
Destination Port - 444

Selected Answer: C
If multiple home users suddenly experience issues with their Cisco Jabber clients, the problem is likely related to something affecting external connectivity or access, which would point to the Cisco Expressway-E.

comments.content: I would differ. If multiple users are reporting the same issue, I would start with the farthest commonality and work my way in.

discussion.content:
Given the scenario described, where home office users suddenly encounter errors while using the Cisco Jabber client, the first thing the engineer should check to resolve this issue is:

A. Client logs of the users.

Checking the client logs of the affected users can provide valuable insights into the nature of the error they are encountering. Client logs often contain detailed information about connection attempts, error messages, and potential issues encountered during the operation of the Jabber client. By analyzing these logs, the engineer can identify the specific problem affecting the users and take appropriate action to resolve it.

choices.D: alarms on the Cisco UCM Cluster
choices.B: real-time monitoring toll logs for problems

questions.question_text: An engineer is supporting an existing Cisco Collaboration deployment that has internal and external home users using the solution without VPN. Business usage also includes B2B calling for voice and video. Suddenly the engineer receives a report that one of the home office users cannot use the Cisco Jabber client, and shortly after, a few more reports come in for the same error. What must the engineer check first to resolve this issue?
